questions.text: A 42-year-old female, presented with sudden onset eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity in her left eye. Examination reveals reduced IOP and anterior chamber inflammation. She is diagnosed with acute iridocyclitis. What is the probable cause of reduced IOP?

questions.text: Lamina vitrea is also known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bruch membrane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. INTERNAL LIMITING MEMBRANE: The internal limiting membrane (ILM) is the innermost layer of the retina :
  • • Option A.
  • • INTERNAL LIMITING MEMBRANE:
  • • innermost layer of the retina
  • • Anatomical Barrier : The ILM forms a barrier between the vitreous humor and the retinal nerve fiber layer. It helps maintain the structural integrity of the retina and separates retinal cells from the vitreous body. Support for Retinal Cells : It provides physical support to the retinal cells, particularly the Müller cells, which are essential for the normal functioning of the retina. Role in Eye Diseases : The ILM is involved in various retinal diseases. In conditions like macular holes and epiretinal membranes, changes in the ILM can lead to vision impairment. Surgical Importance: During vitrectomy, the ILM is often peeled away to relieve traction or to remove epiretinal membranes. Oxygen and Nutrient Diffusion: While the ILM acts as a barrier, it also allows for the diffusion of essential nutrients and oxygen from the vitreous body to the retina, thereby playing a role in the metabolic exchanges necessary for retinal health. Growth Factor Regulation : The ILM may have a role in regulating the availability of growth factors to the retina, which is important for retinal development and repair.

  • • Growth Factor Regulation
  • • The ILM's integrity is crucial for maintaining retinal structure and function. Its role becomes particularly significant in various retinal surgical procedures and in the management of retinal diseases.
  • • Option C. DESCEMET’S MEMBRANE:
  • • Option C.
  • • DESCEMET’S MEMBRANE:
  • • Location and Structure : Descemet's membrane is located between the stroma and the endothelial layer of the cornea . It's a thin, clear layer composed of collagen and other fibers. Function : This membrane serves as a protective barrier for the corneal endothelium and plays a critical role in maintaining corneal hydration and transparency. Development and Growth : Descemet's membrane is unique in that it continues to grow throughout a person's life . The membrane is thicker in older individuals compared to younger ones. Role in Eye Health: Descemet's membrane is crucial for corneal health. Descemet’s membrane detachment or disease affecting can lead to endothelial cell failure with resultant corneal edema, corneal decompensation and vision impairment. Surgical Importance: In certain corneal surgeries, such as lamellar corneal transplants or endothelial keratoplasty, Descemet's membrane is a focal point. DSEK (Descemets stripping endothelial keratoplasty) is performed for treatment of Fuch’s dystrophy. Regeneration Capabilities: Unlike other parts of the cornea, Descemet's membrane has limited regenerative capabilities. If damaged, it doesn't repair or regenerate as effectively as the epithelial layer of the cornea. Clinical Significance: Various corneal diseases, such as keratoconus or endothelial dystrophies, can manifest changes in Descemet's membrane, making its examination important in diagnosing these conditions.

  • • Location and Composition : The ELM is located within the retina, situated between the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) and the outer nuclear layer, which contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptors. Structure: It is not a true membrane but rather a series of junctions—specifically, adherens junctions—between Müller cells and the photoreceptor cells. These junctions appear as a line when viewed under a microscope, hence the term "membrane." Role in Retinal Integrity: The ELM plays a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity of the retina. It helps to organize and stabilize the arrangement of photoreceptor cells. Barrier Function: While it allows for the passage of nutrients and waste products, the ELM also serves as a barrier to larger molecules, thereby protecting the photoreceptor layer. Indication of Retinal Health: In various retinal imaging techniques, such as Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT), the integrity of the ELM is often assessed as an indicator of retinal health. Disruption or irregularity in the ELM can be a sign of retinal diseases or damage. Role in Disease: Changes or damage to the ELM can be involved in various retinal diseases, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal detachment. These conditions can lead to impaired vision or blindness. Regenerative Potential: Unlike some other parts of the retina, the ELM has limited regenerative capacity. Damage to this area can have lasting effects on vision.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with mild ocular redness for the past 4 months. On examination, he had large keratic precipitates with minimal flare. The likely etiology for this condition includes all except?

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Reiter's syndrome , also known as reactive arthritis , is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body , often the intestines, genitals, or urinary tract . It is classified as a form of spondyloarthritis , which is a group of joint diseases that specifically affect the spine and the areas where the tendons and ligaments attach to bones.

  • • The key features of Reiter's syndrome include:
  • • Arthritis : Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine. Urethritis : Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate. Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort. Enthesitis : Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions : Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).

  • • triggered by certain bacterial infections.

Antibiotics may be used if a bacterial infection is identified as the trigger. Additionally, physical therapy can help maintain joint function and range of motion.

questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. AQUEOUS REACTION : In cases of intraocular inflammation, inflammatory cells and flare can be seen on slit lamp examination . This is called aqueous reaction.
  • • Option B.
  • • AQUEOUS REACTION
  • • intraocular inflammation, inflammatory cells and flare can be seen on slit lamp examination
  • • Option D. Iris neovascularization refers to the abnormal growth of new blood vessels on the iris. This condition is typically a secondary response to other ocular or systemic conditions that cause reduced blood flow or oxygenation to the retina . Here's a detailed explanation:
  • • Option D.
  • • Iris neovascularization
  • • abnormal growth of new blood vessels on the iris.
  • • secondary response to other ocular or systemic conditions
  • • reduced blood flow or oxygenation to the retina
  • • Causes : Iris neovascularization is often a result of ischemic conditions within the eye , Common causes include diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion, uveitis, and ischemic central retinal artery occlusion. Systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus and hypertension can also contribute to its development. Pathophysiology: In response to retinal ischemia (lack of blood flow), the body releases growth factors like vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). These factors stimulate the growth of new blood vessels in an attempt to increase blood supply. However, these new vessels are often weak, leaky, and can grow in inappropriate areas like the iris and the angle of the anterior chamber of the eye. Symptoms and Complications : Initially, iris neovascularization may not cause any symptoms . As it progresses, it can lead to complications like neovascular glaucoma, a severe form of glaucoma with high intraocular pressure due to the blockage of the eye’s drainage system by the new vessels. Symptoms may include pain, redness, blurred vision, and vision loss. Diagnosis : It is diagnosed by slit-lamp examination and gonioscopy . Fluorescein angiography may also be used to highlight blood flow in the retina and iris. Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing the underlying cause and preventing complications. Laser therapy, such as panretinal photocoagulation (PRP), can reduce the drive for neovascularization by treating retinal ischemia. Intravitreal injections of anti-VEGF medications directly into the eye can also help by inhibiting the growth factors responsible for the formation of new blood vessels. In advanced cases, surgery may be necessary to manage complications like neovascular glaucoma.
  • • Causes : Iris neovascularization is often a result of ischemic conditions within the eye , Common causes include diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion, uveitis, and ischemic central retinal artery occlusion.   • • Option C . Pupillary Miosis : Pupillary miosis (constriction of the pupil) can occur in inflammatory conditions of the eye due to irritation of the iris , but it is not typically considered the first sign of sympathetic ophthalmia.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about sympathetic ophthalmitis.

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option A . Dalen-Fuchs Nodules Are Present in Retinochoroidal Periphery : This statement is true . Dalen-Fuchs nodules are characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmia and are found in the peripheral retina and choroid. They are aggregates of epithelioid cells and lymphocytes between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.

  • • Option D . Ciliary Body is Called the Dangerous Zone of the Eye : This statement is true . The ciliary body is often referred to as the "dangerous zone" because trauma to this area is thought to increase the risk of developing sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • • Option D
  • • Ciliary Body is Called the Dangerous Zone of the Eye
  • • true

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with RE Right Eye pan ophthalmitis is planned for an evisceration procedure with orbital implants. Which among the following is non-porous?

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . MEDPOR ( Microporous High-Density Polyethylene): MEDPOR is a porous implant material commonly used in orbital reconstruction. Its porosity allows for tissue ingrowth, which can reduce the risk of implant migration and extrusion. MEDPOR's interconnected, open pore structure facilitates fibrovascular in-growth, leading to better integration with the host tissues.
  • • Option A
  • • MEDPOR (
  • • porous implant material commonly used in orbital reconstruction.
  • • Option B . Hydroxyapatite : Hydroxyapatite is a naturally occurring mineral form of calcium apatite . It is a porous material, often used as an orbital implant due to its biocompatibility and osteoconductive properties. The porosity of hydroxyapatite allows for tissue integration, making it less likely to be rejected or extruded.
  • • Option B
  • • Hydroxyapatite
  • • naturally occurring mineral form of calcium apatite
  • • Option D . Aluminium Oxide : Aluminium oxide, also known as alumina is porous and known for its high strength and biocompatibility.
  • • Option D
  • • Aluminium Oxide
  • • known as alumina is porous and known for its high strength and biocompatibility.

  • • eye is the junction of the cornea and the sclera
  • • Functions of Limbus:
  • • Transition Zone : The limbus acts as a transition zone between the transparent cornea and the opaque sclera. This border is necessary for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the eye. Stem Cell Reservoir : The limbus contains stem cells that are crucial for the regeneration and repair of corneal tissue. These limbal stem cells continuously replenish the corneal epithelium. Barrier Function : It serves as a barrier to prevent the conjunctival epithelial cells from migrating onto the corneal surface, which is important for preserving corneal clarity and vision. Nutrient and Waste Exchange : The limbus plays a role in the exchange of nutrients and waste materials between the cornea and the conjunctiva. This is vital for maintaining the health of the corneal cells. Vascular Supply : Although the cornea is avascular (lacking blood vessels) for transparency, the limbus contains blood vessels that supply nutrients to the peripheral cornea and aid in immune responses. Anatomical Markings : Clinically, the limbus is used as a landmark for various eye surgeries and procedures due to its distinct anatomical positioning.

questions.text: Layer of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body is the forward continuation of which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sensory retina

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Pigmented Epithelium of Retina : The pigmented epithelium of the retina is a layer of cells that is essential for the function of the retina . It plays a role in the visual cycle and provides support to the photoreceptors.
  • • Option A
  • • Pigmented Epithelium of Retina
  • • layer of cells that is essential for the function of the retina
  • • Option C . Internal Limiting Membrane: The internal limiting membrane is the boundary between the retina and the vitreous body of the eye . It's the basement membrane of the Müller cells, which are a type of glial cell found in the retina.
  • • Option C
  • • Internal Limiting Membrane:
  • • boundary between the retina and the vitreous body of the eye
  • • Option D . Bruch’s Membrane: Bruch's membrane is part of the choroid, lying between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium. It's a thin, multi-layered structure that plays a role in supporting the retina and facilitating the exchange of nutrients and waste.
  • • Option D
  • • Bruch’s Membrane:
  • • part of the choroid, lying between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sensory retina continues forward as the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body .
  • ➤ The sensory retina continues forward as the non-pigmented epithelium
